While there's definitely still times where I feel like I'm not doing enough or learning enough about tech/coding/etc especially when I compare my work to others in this space (seriously, y'all are friggin rocking it 🤘), I feel less rushed to figure it all out.

I'm noticing how weird it is that I would bully myself for stuff like this, and it's hard to tell exactly how I got there. Maybe it doesn't have to do with living in/out of the bay at all. Maybe it has to do with how much more sun I'm getting. Or my breakthroughs in therapy.

It's been two months since I moved out of Silicon Valley and... I feel so much more relaxed (or as much as I could be, during COVID). No longer counting days as "good" or "bad" based on productivity, and I don't feel guilty doing things that aren't work.

What do you think the world would look like if the tech industry slowed down a lil bit? My (perhaps naive) guesses: 👆Less burnout 👆More thoughtful and intentional technology 👆More mentorship & training for jr. devs

@vndlgd98 I believe heavily in justice/fairness/balance which is why warren spoke to me. But I would’ve been okay at other colleges too. I hope this was helpful!!

@vndlgd98 But it’ll be where you *start* college. And will heavily influence what you learn in your first 2 years as you’re doing GEs and lower divs. I would read up on each college’s wiki and choose based on the values of each college that speak to you!

@vndlgd98 In the end you’re going to make the right choice and your college won’t determine everything about ur college exp: you can still take whatever classes you want (wrt prereqs), theres lots of opportunities to make other friends, most people move off campus later on, etc.

@vndlgd98 Your college will also determine who’ll be your first group of friends at UCSD too, more or less. Warren has lots of engineers, Revelle has bio, ERC has humanities, etc. oh and it’ll decide which dorms you’ll live in to.

@vndlgd98 It honestly doesn’t matter too much at the end of the day which college you choose - it really depends on what else you want to get out of your college education and what else you want to learn. I wish I took way more humanities classes in college to round out the CS curriculum

@vndlgd98 This was great bc the CS curriculum at UCSD was really demanding and had a LOT of requirements (which eng mjrs tend to have). The classes I did take were actually really valuable bc I needed to take classes in ethics and philosophy which I think are essential coursework for engs

@vndlgd98 Ok hol’ up, imma answer this Q right here cuz it’s good but also really specific. I went to warren college - I’m not sure if this is still the case, but back then, engineering majors in warren only needed to take half the GEs compared to other colleges & other majors at warren.

@MiddlingMe So much 🤦🏻‍♀️😡😖. I’ve been told this in my classes too. I don’t understand who this benefits. Professors and teachers are supposed to empower and teach. Not alienate and degrade students.

Every person currently in tech was mentored and sponsored for opportunities to learn and grow. And this mentorship needs to keep extending to the next gen. It’s a “business risk”, if you wanna call it that. I call it investing in your (and the industry as a whole)’s future.

The holes include (but are not limited to) the inaccessibility of a 4 year degree program, students and prospective being told they’re not “good enough” by those in the industry and getting discouraged, and companies relying on other companies to train new grads/engineers.

The disconnect I feel between the tons of people wanting to get into the tech industry and then companies saying there’s a “talent shortage”... 🤔 there’s a leaky bucket somewhere. https://t.co/DwECsw8D9n
